lens.lens_summary: A weekend-stay guest confused about platform mechanics reveals that SplitLease's design fails to articulate its own decisions — the UI doesn't explain why things work the way they do, creating friction that only a phone call can resolve.

discovery.what_this_lens_reveals: Theodore discovered SplitLease but simultaneously submitted an Airbnb request, revealing he doesn't understand the fundamental difference between the two platforms. The UI fails to articulate what SplitLease IS in a way that separates it from short-term rentals. Greever's framework says the design must 'solve a problem' — but if the guest can't see WHAT problem SplitLease solves (mid-term flexible stays cheaper than Airbnb), discovery fails. The agent had to explain: 'Airbnb can never compete with us on the price' (06:32) — this should be the UI's job.

user_state.emotional_state: Confused but open — 'I'm confused' (00:24) but willing to listen
user_state.knowledge_level: Minimal — conflates SplitLease with Airbnb, doesn't understand split scheduling
user_state.commitment_level: Browsing/exploring — submitted a bid but doesn't understand what a bid means
user_state.data_available: Name, location preference, desired days (weekend), approximate budget

reasons: Doesn't understand platform differentiation from Airbnb
Submitted to both platforms simultaneously — will go with whichever responds first
No self-service path to understand the nights-of-the-week model
dropout_risk.evidence: Theodore: 'Now I am confused. So you want to... you want to rent out your place and you also want to add something else.' (00:24) — he doesn't even know if he's a host or guest.

key_quotes.relevance: The platform's discovery experience creates confusion rather than clarity — violates Greever's principle that design must communicate what it does.

key_quotes.quote: Airbnb can never compete with us on the price.
key_quotes.relevance: This critical differentiator is only communicated verbally by the agent, not by the UI.

key_quotes.quote: The difference between a good designer and a great designer is the ability to not only solve the problem, but to also articulate how the design solves it.
key_quotes.relevance: SplitLease's UI solves the matching problem but fails to articulate HOW it does so — requiring agents to fill the gap.

search.what_this_lens_reveals: Theodore asked 'Can you tell me a little bit about how long you've been around and where you're located and what areas you serve?' (07:06). He cannot find this basic information through the UI. The search experience doesn't communicate company legitimacy or geographic scope. His weekend pattern (Fri-Sun) is a less common configuration, and the agent implied matching might be 'a little more tricky' (11:32), but the UI provides no feedback on match likelihood before the guest invests time.

user_state.emotional_state: Cautious but engaged — asking due diligence questions
user_state.knowledge_level: Understands concept of day-splitting after agent explanation
user_state.data_available: Weekend pattern (Fri-Sun), NYC area, ~16 weeks duration, flexible on specifics

reasons: Weekend patterns harder to match than weekday
No feedback on match probability before investing time
Agent acknowledged location restrictions may limit options
dropout_risk.evidence: Agent: 'What I am concerned is your location. If you are starting seriously strict in locations, that's where things might be a little more tricky' (11:32)

key_quotes.quote: Can you tell me a little bit about how long you've been around and where you're located?
key_quotes.relevance: Basic platform credibility information that the UI should communicate prominently but doesn't.

key_quotes.quote: We need to see the world through the eyes of the people who have influence over our project.
key_quotes.relevance: The guest's search experience needs to be designed from THEIR perspective — showing match probability and platform legitimacy, not just listings.

listing_evaluation.what_this_lens_reveals: Theodore asked about seeing the apartment: 'At one point we'll actually get to see the apartment before I sign the lease' (04:07). The agent corrected him — you sign first, then get 24 hours. This is a CRITICAL severity friction: the guest's mental model (see before signing) conflicts with the actual flow (sign, then inspect). Greever's framework calls this a failure to 'anticipate reactions' — the UI doesn't prepare the guest for this inverted expectation. The Airbnb analogy the agent used ('does anybody come to see your apartment?') was effective verbally but absent from the UI.

user_state.emotional_state: Anxious about committing without seeing the space — 'stumped' by the 24-hour model
user_state.knowledge_level: Incorrectly assumes traditional apartment viewing before commitment
user_state.commitment_level: Hesitant — needs the agent's Airbnb analogy to overcome objection
user_state.data_available: Specific listing interest, but unsure about commitment mechanism

reasons: Mental model mismatch: expects to see apartment before signing
24-hour inspection period is unfamiliar and anxiety-inducing
No visual/UI explanation of the protection model
dropout_risk.evidence: Theodore: 'And of course everything is built video. So at one point we'll actually get to see the apartment before I signed the lease.' Agent: 'No, no, not before you signed the lease' (04:17-04:20)

key_quotes.quote: You will see the apartment... not before you signed the lease, you sign the lease and you have this 24 hour period.
key_quotes.relevance: The most critical severity point in the guest journey — the 24-hour protection model needs to be articulated by the UI with the same persuasive power the agent uses.

key_quotes.quote: When you rent your apartment over Airbnb, does anybody come to see your apartment? That's true. That's fair. That's a good point.
key_quotes.relevance: The Airbnb analogy instantly resolved Theodore's objection — this reframing technique must be embedded in the UI.

proposal_creation.what_this_lens_reveals: Theodore submitted a 'bid' but doesn't understand what bids do. He asks: 'What is kind of the purpose of submitting a bid? Will you let me know higher?' (07:35-07:47). The bid/proposal mechanism is opaque — he thinks it's like an auction. The agent explains it's an 'indication of interest and how much you are willing to pay' (07:47-08:06). Greever's severity framework would classify this as MAJOR: the guest takes a critical action (submitting a proposal) without understanding its implications.

user_state.emotional_state: Uncertain about what he committed to by submitting a bid
user_state.knowledge_level: Misunderstands bid as auction-like, not as expression of interest
user_state.commitment_level: Has already submitted a bid, but doesn't understand what it means
user_state.data_available: Bid submitted with dates, price willingness, preferred days

reasons: Doesn't understand what the bid/proposal actually does
Unclear on timeline expectations
May submit competing bids on other platforms out of anxiety
dropout_risk.evidence: Theodore: 'What is kind of the purpose of submitting a bid? Will you let me know higher? Or like, how did that work?' (07:35-07:47)

key_quotes.quote: What is kind of the purpose of submitting a bid? Will you let me know higher?
key_quotes.relevance: The proposal flow doesn't articulate its own purpose — Greever's core failing: design that doesn't explain itself.

key_quotes.quote: What problem does it solve? How does it affect the user? Why is it better than the alternative?
key_quotes.relevance: The proposal confirmation must answer these three questions for the guest about their own submission.

negotiation.what_this_lens_reveals: The agent explains the matching and counter-offer process will take '2-3 weeks complete the process' (08:40). Theodore is surprised: 'Oh, that's for the whole process.' The agent clarifies batched matching happens weekly. The negotiation phase is invisible to the guest — there's no status, no timeline, no indication of progress. Greever's framework emphasizes 'follow up fast' and 'manage expectations.' The current design fails both.

user_state.emotional_state: Slightly anxious about timeline — accustomed to instant Airbnb responses
user_state.knowledge_level: Now understands batched matching but has no way to track progress
user_state.commitment_level: Committed enough to wait, but vulnerability to competitor poaching is high
user_state.data_available: Bid submitted, waiting for match results

reasons: 2-3 week wait with no status updates
No visibility into matching progress
Airbnb provides instant booking — the comparison is unfavorable
dropout_risk.evidence: Agent: 'Give us two to three weeks to complete the process' (08:40). Theodore needs status feedback during this critical waiting period.

key_quotes.quote: Give us two to three weeks... Oh, that's for the whole process. So I may get back with you even sooner, maybe next week.
key_quotes.relevance: The timeline is opaque until explained verbally. The UI must set expectations and provide progress visibility.

acceptance.what_this_lens_reveals: The agent describes acceptance as: 'you have no obligation for anything until you sign the lease' (03:01-03:14). Then payment is held until 24-hour inspection passes. This is a multi-step acceptance with unusual financial safeguards that must be communicated clearly. Greever's principle: 'we need to harness the power of communication and be articulate' — the acceptance flow must articulate each safeguard step explicitly.

user_state.emotional_state: Needs reassurance that financial commitment is protected
user_state.knowledge_level: Understands basic flow after agent explanation, but UI hasn't reinforced it
user_state.commitment_level: Will commit if safeguards are clearly communicated
user_state.data_available: Agreed terms, payment method on file

reasons: Financial commitment anxiety without seeing space
Complex safeguard model (24-hour hold, security deposit with SplitLease)
No prior experience with this payment model
dropout_risk.evidence: Theodore: 'Good point. Awesome.' (04:50-05:03) — he accepted only after the Airbnb analogy. The UI must provide equivalent persuasive context.

key_quotes.quote: You have no obligation for anything until you sign the lease. We hold the payment until you spend at least 24 hours in the property.
key_quotes.relevance: The protection model is the key trust mechanism — must be articulated visually with the same step-by-step clarity the agent uses.

move_in.what_this_lens_reveals: Theodore expects a Zoom meeting with the host before move-in: 'It's going to be a Zoom meeting which we will facilitate' (02:18). This is a shared-experience creation mechanism that Greever identifies as essential for trust-building. The move-in phase should bridge the digital-to-physical transition with the same personal touch the agent promises. Theodore also asks about the landlord relationship — the three-party dynamic (guest, host, SplitLease) needs clear articulation at move-in.

user_state.emotional_state: Anticipatory — expects personal introduction before committing fully
user_state.knowledge_level: Understands Zoom introduction is part of process
user_state.commitment_level: High if the in-person/video experience matches expectations
user_state.data_available: Match confirmed, Zoom scheduled, lease documents pending

reasons: First physical impression may not match listing
24-hour inspection window creates time pressure
No digital house manual or move-in guide mentioned
dropout_risk.evidence: Theodore understands the protection model but needs the move-in experience to reinforce that protection is real, not theoretical.

key_quotes.quote: It's going to be a Zoom meeting which we will facilitate.
key_quotes.relevance: The facilitated video introduction is a shared-experience creation mechanism (Greever Ch 2) that builds trust before physical commitment.

active_lease.what_this_lens_reveals: Theodore signed up for the 40% discount tier which requires flexibility and cleaning/chores. The agent explains: 'for less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount' (12:43-12:55). This creates a weekly contract between the guest and the platform — Theodore must maintain cleaning standards AND be flexible on days to keep his discount. The Stays Manager must track and communicate this ongoing bargain. Greever's framework says you must 'manage expectations' — the active lease must continuously articulate what the guest committed to and what they're getting in return.

user_state.emotional_state: Motivated by savings but needs ongoing validation that the bargain is worth it
user_state.knowledge_level: Understands the trade-off conceptually but hasn't experienced it yet
user_state.commitment_level: High — 16 weeks minimum, weekly recurring engagement
user_state.data_available: Cleaning compliance, schedule flexibility, payment history, stay count

reasons: 40% discount obligation may feel burdensome over 16 weeks
No feedback loop showing discount value vs. effort
Cleaning and flexibility requirements could feel punitive without positive framing
dropout_risk.evidence: Agent: 'If you keep the place clean and... willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount' (12:07-12:55). The weekly value must be made tangible.

key_quotes.quote: For less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.
key_quotes.relevance: The discount tier creates a weekly engagement loop — the Stays Manager must show the guest how much they're saving through their effort, making the bargain visible.

key_quotes.quote: Projects that fail are usually lacking in one of these areas... It solves a problem. It's easy for users. It's supported by everyone.
key_quotes.relevance: The active lease must continuously prove it solves the guest's problem (affordable housing), is easy (cleaning/flexibility isn't burdensome), and is supported (the host appreciates their effort).

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Design fails to articulate its own decisions — requiring human agents to fill the communication gap
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Theodore's call is 14 minutes of an agent explaining what the UI should communicate: what SplitLease is (00:24), how bids work (07:35), why you can't see the apartment first (04:17), how matching works (08:40), and what the 40% discount requires (12:43). Every one of these is a severity-CRITICAL communication gap in the UI.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The Airbnb mental model creates false expectations that must be reframed, not just corrected
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Theodore submitted to both SplitLease and Airbnb simultaneously (00:11). He expected apartment viewings like Airbnb (04:07). The agent's reframing ('does anybody come to see your Airbnb apartment?') was instantly persuasive (04:50). The UI needs reframing language, not just information.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: The 40% discount tier creates a behavioral contract that shapes the entire active lease experience
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Theodore eagerly signed up for the discount (12:07), but the ongoing obligations (flexibility + chores) will define his weekly experience for 16+ weeks. The UI must continuously articulate the value exchange, not just at signup.

cross_phase_patterns.pattern: Weekend-stay guests have different matching dynamics than weekday guests but get the same generic experience
cross_phase_patterns.evidence: Agent acknowledged weekend matching is 'a little more tricky' (11:32) because most hosts want full occupancy. Weekend guests need different expectation-setting, match probability feedback, and potentially different pricing visibility.
